subjectDescription: Discover a full suite of online business courses that will allow you to make better business decisions and succeed in today's competitive business world. Our courses provide a rich learning experience that will allow you to develop critical business skills in areas such as business... Read more...
title: Application of Law to Business Enterprise
headline: Learn about the relationship between the legal system and business enterprises in this free online course.
description: Are you thinking of establishing a company and want to know what law governs the operations of business enterprises? Commercial law is the body of law that covers individuals' and businesses' rights, relations and conduct. In this course, you will learn about the general nature of law, distinguish the various types of law and apply it to business enterprises. This knowledge will help you to stay fully compliant with the law.

Define ‘commercial law’ and establis...
Distinguish commercial law from corp...
Describe statute law and delegated l...
State the difference between crimina...
Define ‘commercial law’ and establish the importance of law
Distinguish commercial law from corporate governance
Describe statute law and delegated legislation
State the difference between criminal law and civil law
Outline the essential elements of a contract
List the rules relating to offer and acceptance
Discuss the concepts of joint ventures, licensing and agency
courseDescription:
The law has many functions in modern society. Some of the major ones are determining standards, sustaining order, settling disputes and protecting rights. This course contains two modules. The first introduces you to the legal system, business and corporation law and related matters. You will explore the common law and statutory principles of the commercial environment and corporate governance. Other topics include the application of law to business enterprise and contract law. Contract law is concerned with the rules that govern agreements. Business requires that agreements be honoured by the performance of the promises made to ensure that expectations are fulfilled. In addition, you will learn about the difference between insolvency and bankruptcy. There are several business structures to choose from when starting or expanding a business. We will spend time analysing these to enable you to select the one most suitable for your vision.

The second module examines essential elements of corporation law, including the concept of a separate legal entity, company formation and operation and corporate governance. Topics include but are not limited to companies and trusts (Private and Listed), joint ventures, licensing and agency, non-profit organisations (NGOs), corporate governance and business ethics and compliance. Once you form a company, it becomes a separate legal entity. Those who create the company are known as its ‘promoters’. If they do not carry out their tasks under the common law and statute, they will be liable to the company for breach of their fiduciary duties - hence the need to be well grounded in the common law and statute. Membership of the company does not occur until you enter the allottee’s name into the register of members. Discover the means of becoming a member of a company, shareholders’ rights and the duties, appointment and disqualification of a director in a corporation

In the corporate world, sometimes there is a need for company owners to come together to create synergies, which leads you to the concepts of merger and acquisition. Research the difference between friendly takeovers and the takeover prohibitions and exempt acquisition. Following that, investigate the management and regulation of the information systems established by a company to accomplish its objectives. This course will benefit you if you desire to launch your own company, especially in Australia. By enrolling, you will understand how companies come into existence and the relevant laws applicable to business enterprises. This course will set you on the right path, and you will never have to worry about legal problems. Click on the start button and register today!

Start Course Now
certificateDetail:
All Alison courses are free to enrol study and complete. To successfully complete this certificate course and become an Alison Graduate, you need to achieve 80% or higher in each course assessment. Once you have completed this certificate course, you have the option to acquire an official Diploma, which is a great way to share your achievement with the world.

Your Alison certificate is:
  • Ideal for sharing with potential employers
  • Include it in your CV, professional social media profiles and job applications.
  • An indication of your commitment to continuously learn, upskill & achieve high results.
  • An incentive for you to continue empowering yourself through lifelong learning.
Alison offers 3 types of Diplomas for completed Diploma courses:
  • Digital certificate: a downloadable certificate in PDF format immediately available to you when you complete your purchase.
  • certificate: a physical version of your officially branded and security-marked certificate, posted to you with FREE shipping.
  • Framed certificate: a physical version of your officially branded and security marked certificate in a stylish frame, posted to you with FREE shipping.
Start Course Now

All certificate are available to purchase through the Alison Shop. For more information on purchasing Alison certificate, please visit our FAQs. If you decide not to purchase your Alison certificate, you can still demonstrate your achievement by sharing your Learner Record or Learner Achievement Verification, both of which are accessible from your Dashboard. For more details on our certificate pricing, please visit our Pricing Page

modules.name: Module
modules.description: This module will introduce you to the legal system and the fundamentals of corporate law. You will learn about the common law and statutory principles relating to the commercial environment, corporate governance, key features of a contract, application of law to business enterprise, terms of a contract, offer and acceptance.
topics: Corporate Law Fundamentals and Application - Learning Outcomes
Overview of Corporate Law and Governance
Application of Law to Business Enterprise and Contract Law
Corporate Law Fundamentals and Application - Lesson Summary

modules.name: Module
modules.description: In this module, you will learn about company formation and operation, corporate governance, companies and trusts, joint ventures, non-profit organisations, business ethics and compliance. Then you will explore the application of the law relating to directors, management and members’ rights.

modules.name: Module
topics: Application of Law to Business Enterprise - Course Assessment

slides:
• Learning Outcomes

  • Having completed this module you will be able to:
    • Define commercial law and state the importance of law.
    • Distinguish commercial law from corporate governance.
    • Explain common equity law.
    • Describe statute law and delegated legislation.
    • State the difference between criminal law and civil law.
    • Outline the essential elements of a contract.
    • List the rules relating to offer and acceptance.
    • Discuss the concepts of joint ventures, licensing and agency.

  • Employment Law

  • Employment law also known as labour law covers the relationship between workers (employees), employers, trade unions and the government. In many countries employment law is focused on the rights and obligations of the worker and the employer. The employment contract is subject to various legal provisions. 

    For example, generally, an employer may not offer a contract that pays the worker less than a minimum wage.

  • Select an Image from the Gallery

  • Employment law comprises the entire body of regulations relating to the individual employment relationship between the employers on the one hand and the employee on the other. In general, its coverage includes the legal capacity to conclude an individual contract of employment, the nature and various types of individual contracts of employment, part-time work, probation clauses, the respective obligations and rights of employer and employee, suspension of the performance of the employment contract and termination of employment (including the closure of an enterprise and collective dismissal or redundancy), and also quittances acknowledging settlement, non-competition covenants, arbitration clauses, limitation of actions and penalty payments .

  • Lesson Summary

    • Corporations are created by statute. The Corporations Act 2001 sets out the various types of companies that are allowed and the method by which a company is brought into existence.
    • A company comes into existence on registration: the separate legal entity principle.
    • ‘Corporation’ is a general term comprising any body corporate and certain unincorporated bodies.
    • A company acts through its agents. Agents may be held personally liable if they do not in fact have the power they claim to.
    • Trust is not: a separate legal entity; not a product of a contract but arises under the law of equity.
    • Corporate governance comprises balancing the interests of the stakeholders, management, customers, suppliers, government and the community. 
    • Every company must keep a register of members and such register is prima facie evidence of any matters inserted therein.
    • The law provides that the business of a company is to be managed or directed by the directors.
    • “A policy of insurance, even one required by statute, is a commercial contract and should be given a businesslike interpretation.
    • IT governance encompasses IT strategy and business strategy. It allows businesses to take into account all stakeholders’ interests and provides some measurable results.

  • Learning Outcomes

  • Having completed this module you will be able to:
    • Explain industrial relations and employment law.
    • Define intellectual property and explain the attributes of intellectual property rights.
    • Distinguish bankruptcy from insolvency law.
    • Discuss taxation law, types of taxes and the sources of tax in Australia.
    • List the key elements of an effective compliance program.
    • Describe the board structure, the duties and the roles of the director in a corporation.
    • Identify the disqualification of persons from managing a corporation.
    • Recognize the differences between market and off-market bids.

  • Risk and Insurance

  • Insurance is essentially all about risk, with insurers gambling that the event for which they've insured you will not occur. This 'gamble' is a calculated risk and one which is governed by both common law and legislation.

    The basic principle underlying most contracts of insurance is that of indemnity. In this situation, the insurer will pay the amount of the insured's actual loss up to the amount specified by the insurance contract. However, there are some contracts where this principle does not apply, for instance life insurance policies and personal accident policies.

  • Select an Image from the Gallery

  • The Insurance Contracts Act 1984 (Cth) provides the basics in respect of for the requirements of a valid insurance contract. The legislation supports many of the common law principles which impact upon insurance contracts such as:
    • Insurable interest.
    •  The duty of good faith
    • The duty of disclosure.
    • Misrepresentation

  • Risk and Insurance

  • Insurance is essentially all about risk, with insurers gambling that the event for which they've insured you will not occur. This 'gamble' is a calculated risk and one which is governed by both common law and legislation.

    The basic principle underlying most contracts of insurance is that of indemnity. In this situation, the insurer will pay the amount of the insured's actual loss up to the amount specified by the insurance contract. However, there are some contracts where this principle does not apply, for instance life insurance policies and personal accident policies.

  • Select an Image from the Gallery

    • Insurable interest.
    •  The duty of good faith
    • The duty of disclosure.
    • Misrepresentation

  • Risk and Insurance

  • Insurance is essentially all about risk, with insurers gambling that the event for which they've insured you will not occur. This 'gamble' is a calculated risk and one which is governed by both common law and legislation.

    The basic principle underlying most contracts of insurance is that of indemnity. In this situation, the insurer will pay the amount of the insured's actual loss up to the amount specified by the insurance contract. However, there are some contracts where this principle does not apply, for instance life insurance policies and personal accident policies.

    • Insurable interest.

    • The duty of disclosure.
    • Misrepresentation

  • Lesson Summary

    • Employment law, also known as Labour Law, covers the relationship between workers (employees), employers, trade unions and the government.
    • Employment law comprises the entire body of regulations relating to the individual employment relationship between the employers on the one hand and the employee on the other.
    • Intellectual Property (IP) generally refers to something new or original.
    • Intellectual property rights provide an incentive to innovate and the time and opportunity for IP owners to exploit their creations.
    • Insolvency can be defined as the inability to pay one's debts as they fall due.
    • Bankruptcy is the approach by which the normal rights of a creditor are withheld in the interests of the debtor and by which the law of debt is modified to effect a compromise beneficial to all parties.
    • Taxation is the chief source of government revenue.
    • Antitrust law is developed to protect consumers from voracious business practices by ensuring that fair competition exists in an open-market economy.
    • A board of directors is a group of individuals who control the general business activities of a corporation. "Directors" are generally officers of a corporation who form the Board of Directors.
    • The basic principle underlying most contracts of insurance is that of indemnity.
